{{for|the modern-day burial ground|Sanhedria Cemetery}} {{Infobox cemetery | name = Tombs of the Sanhedrin | image = V12p186001 Tombs.jpg | imagesize = | caption = Burial niches in the main chamber | map_type = | map_size = | map_caption = | established = 1st century A.D. | country = Israel | location = [[Sanhedria]], [[Jerusalem]] | coordinates = | latitude = | longitude = | type = [[Rock-cut tombs in Israel|Rock-cut tombs]] | style = | owner = | size = | graves = 63 | interments = | cremations = | leases = | website = | findagrave = | political = }} '''Tombs of the Sanhedrin''' ({{lang-he-n|קברי הסנהדרין}}, ''Kivrei HaSanhedrin''), also called '''Tombs of the Judges''', is an underground complex of 63 [[Rock-cut tombs in Israel|rock-cut tombs]] located in a public park in the northern [[Jerusalem]] neighborhood of [[Sanhedria]]. Constructed in the 1st century A.D., the tombs are noted for their elaborate design and symmetry. They have been a site for Jewish pilgrimage since the medieval period. ==Name== The Tombs of the Sanhedrin have been known by different names among Jews and Christians. In 1235 Rabbi Jacob the Emissary called them the "Tombs of the Righteous", writing that the tombs housed the remains of "many wise men".{{cite web |url=http://jlifeguides.com/en/sights/other/tombs-of-the-sanhedrin-13528/view-details.html|title=Tombs of the Sanhedrin |publisher=JLife |accessdate=12 October 2012}} They were first called the Tombs of the Sanhedrin by Rabbi Joseph Halevi in 1450, and have been known by that name among Jews ever since. In Christian literature, Joannes Cotovicus mentioned the tombs, without naming them, in 1598. In 1611 English traveler [[George Sandys]] called them the "Tombs of the Prophets". They were named "Tombs of the Judges" – referring to the "judges" of the [[Sanhedrin|Great Sanhedrin]] – by [[Franciscus Quaresmius]] in the early 1600s. This is the name they are known by among non-Jews. [[File:Sanhedrin1.jpg|right|thumb|250px|An 1893 encyclopedia illustration of the [[Sanhedrin]] in session.]] In the absence of identifying plaques or other indications as to the ownership of the tomb, historians speculate that the name "Tombs of the Sanhedrin" was applied because the tombs contain nearly as many burial niches as the number of members (71 to 73) of the [[Sanhedrin]], the Jewish Supreme Court in the era of the [[Second Temple]].[https://books.google.com/books?id=7MK_spizMQwC&pg=PA79&lpg=PA79&dq=tomb+of+the+sanhedrin&source=bl&ots=seJ7KD9qJp&sig=J7QKQlnkyrTyq1tP5EzzUb4N8qs&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ev91UMiOI8Or0QWc7oDgCw&ved=0CDkQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=tomb%20of%20the%20sanhedrin&f=false "Sanhedriya – 'Tomb of the Judges' or 'Tomb of the Sanhedrin'"], in ''Corpus Inscriptionum Iudaeae/Palaestinae'', Volume 1: Jerusalem, Part 1, 1-704. Cotton, Hannah M. et al, eds. 2010: Walter de Gruyter, {{ISBN|3110222205}}, p. 79. However, many archeologists refute this correlation.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7eDxQk0MjhcC&pg=PA492&lpg=PA492&dq=sanhedrin+tombs+bodies&source=bl&ots=IgpSzxe_Cu&sig=EE91s1cSdIiB718vP6eQvj_jL9w&hl=en&sa=X&ei=_eCCUKebOvKb1AWmhYDwBg&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=sanhedrin%20tombs%20bodies&f=false |title=The Lands of the Bible Visited and Described |volume=1|first=John |last=Wilson |publisher=White |year=1847 |page=492}} In ''Durchs Heilige Land'' ([[Basel]], 1878), a journal of travel in the Holy Land, Swiss theologian [[Hans Konrad von Orelli]] said he believed that the Tombs of the Sanhedrin and the [[Tombs of the Kings (Jerusalem)|Tombs of the Kings]] (''Kivrei HaMelakhim'') were not necessarily connected to the names people associated with them. Instead, this could have been a burial cave for a wealthy Jewish family."Ancient Jerusalem's Funerary Customs and Tombs: Part Three Ancient Jerusalem's Funerary Customs and Tombs: Part Three, L. Y. Rahmani, The Biblical Archaeologist, Vol. 45, No. 1 (Winter, 1982), pp. 43–53. The Tombs of the Sanhedrin have been a site for Jewish pilgrimage and prayer since the thirteenth century. Since medieval times, Jews considered the tombs holy and would not pass by them without stopping to pray there.{{cite book |last=Ben-Arieh |first=Yehoshua |script-title=he:עיר בראי תקופה: ירושלים החדשה בראשיתה|trans-title=A City Reflected in its Times: New Jerusalem – The Beginnings |language=Hebrew|publisher=Yad Izhak Ben-Zvi Publications |location=Jerusalem |year=1979|page=39}} In the mid-1800s, the tombs were demarcated by a huge boulder that guided pilgrims to the site.Ben Arieh (1979), p. 38. ==Location and size== [[File:Sanhedria Park tombs.jpg|225px|right|thumb|Other rock-cut tombs in [[Sanhedria]] Park]] The Tombs of the Sanhedrin are located at the head of the [[Valley of Josaphat|Valley of Jehoshaphat]] in northwest Jerusalem.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KG5CAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA527&lpg=PA527&dq=tombs+of+the+judges&source=bl&ots=jxkGhdIywR&sig=8kg6E8EA1cBcITy3fn-VXxJx6jM&hl=en&sa=X&ei=jrl5UN3oLYKt0QWD24HwDw&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=tombs%20of%20the%20judges&f=false |title=Biblical Researches in Palestine, Mount Sinai and Arabia Petraea: A Journal of Travels in the Year 1838 |first1=Edward |last1=Robinson |first2=Eli |last2=Smith |publisher=Murray |year=1841}} They are part of a giant [[List of necropoleis|necropolis]] situated to the north and east of the [[Old City (Jerusalem)|Old City of Jerusalem]] and dating to the Second Temple period. Archeologists have surveyed close to 1,000 burial caves within {{convert|3|mi}} of the Old City dating to this period. Graves were most likely placed at great distances from the Old City in order to preserve the special [[Tumah and taharah|laws of purity]] incumbent on [[Kohen|priests]] serving in the [[Temple in Jerusalem]].{{cite web |url=http://www.jerusalem.muni.il/english/sys/tour/vir_tour/show/show_tour.asp?tour_id=85 |title= From the Sanhedrin Tombs to Jason's Tomb|accessdate=10 October 2012 |publisher=Jerusalem Municipality}} Rock-cut tombs like those of the Tombs of the Sanhedrin were typically commissioned by wealthy Jewish families of the era, with monumental facades carved with floral and geometric [[Motif (visual arts)|motifs]].{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=27nq65cZUIgC&pg=PA268&lpg=PA268&dq=tomb+of+the+sanhedrin&source=bl&ots=8bD9CnFkJp&sig=XCytriPi2_BAx-WTFGPkpKm_qsw&hl=en&sa=X&ei=lgJ2UMySH--N0wWXiYG4Dg&ved=0CEwQ6AEwBjgK#v=onepage&q=tomb%20of%20the%20sanhedrin&f=false |title=Archaeological Encyclopedia of the Holy Land |first1=Avraham |last1=Negev |first2=Shimon |last2=Gibson |publisher=Continuum International Publishing Group |year=2005 |page=268 |isbn=0826485715}} The underground complex covers an area of approximately {{convert|10|dunam}}.{{cite web |url=http://www.antiquities.org.il/images/archinfo//001-030/018.pdf |title=Sanhedriyya – Archeological Appendix |publisher=Jerusalem Municipality |date=Spring 2002 |accessdate=18 October 2012}} In the 1950s the Jerusalem municipality planted [[pine]] trees around the site, which is in close proximity to several other 1st- and 2nd-century rock-cut tombs, and created a public park called Sanhedria Park. The adjacent Jewish neighborhood of Sanhedria was also named for the tombs.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TRc9ea_CKOUC&pg=RA1-PA367&lpg=RA1-PA367&dq=sanhedria+neighborhood+named+after+tombs+of+sanhedrin&source=bl&ots=IRloKyUzRs&sig=jo81REG6MHPkFCgBuxkj0otXzGs&hl=en&sa=X&ei=5sh5ULHALMOq0AXq04DgBg&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=sanhedria%20neighborhood%20named%20after%20tombs%20of%20sanhedrin&f=false |page=367 |title= Israel and the Palestinian Territories: The Rough Guide |first1=Daniel |last1=Jacobs |first2=Shirley |last2=Eber|first3=Francesca|last3=Silvani |publisher=Rough Guides |year=1998 |isbn= 1858282489}} ==Description== [[File:Sanhedrin tombs 2.jpg|200px|left|thumb|Forecourt and outer entrance to the Tombs of the Sanhedrin.]] The tombs were constructed on the site of an ancient [[quarry]], with a forecourt at one end and the burial caves excavated out of the other end. The forecourt has benches hewn out of the rock for the benefit of visitors. The forecourt opens onto a small courtyard, walled on three sides. An elaborately carved Grecian{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2diqr_IIm8sC&pg=PA186&lpg=PA186&dq=tombs+of+the+judges&source=bl&ots=W55k18y-D5&sig=0eScICBLg1ufg0ziKxFUCuCoV7Q&hl=en&sa=X&ei=jrl5UN3oLYKt0QWD24HwDw&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=tombs%20of%20the%20judges&f=false |pages=186–187 |title=The City of the Great King |first=James Turner |last=Barclay |year=1858 |publisher=Arno Press|isbn= 0405102259}} [[pediment]] above the large, square entrance is decorated with plant motifs, including [[Acanthus (ornament)|acanthus leaves]] entwined with [[pomegranate]]s and [[Ficus|figs]], representative of [[Judeo-Hellenistic]] burial art of the 1st century.{{cite web |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9Z2cFY9iGqgC&pg=PA107&lpg=PA107&dq=sanhedrin+tomb&source=bl&ots=oNlYD2A71w&sig=DeCa31FtmXW4wqYGCYPqYy1Kpak&hl=en&sa=X&ei=abN5ULrUMYO40QXB5ICgBw&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=sanhedrin%20tomb&f=false |pages=107–108 |title=Golden Jerusalem |first=Menashe |last=Har-El |publisher=Gefen Publishing House |year=2004 |isbn=9652292540}} The inner entrance to the tombs is topped by a small pediment{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=m3Yy9FDcT8gC&pg=PT139&lpg=PT139&dq=sanhedrin+tomb&source=bl&ots=Hu7xYxVDN3&sig=MRoCK3LgdC9SLg8kyamYZhS6zjc&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Yax5UJ7THIb80QWv_oBo&redir_esc=y |page=139 |title=The Holy Land:An Oxford Archaeological Guide from Earliest Times to 1700 |first=Jerome |last=Murphy-O'Connor|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2008|isbn=0191647667}} and was originally sealed by a stone door. The facade of the tomb appeared differently in medieval times. One report describes a "beautiful structure" containing "caves within caves". A 1659 drawing shows an entrance with a grand, arched [[colonnade]]. [[File:Sanhedrin inside.jpg|330px|right|thumb|Burial niches in the main chamber.]] Inside are four burial chambers on two levels. The largest chamber, just inside the entrance, contains 13 arched [[Loculus (architecture)|loculi]] (burial niches) arranged on two tiers, one atop the other, with [[arcosolia]] dividing the niches into pairs. Each niche measures {{convert|50|cm}} by {{convert|60|cm}}. A further 9 burial niches are located in a second chamber off the first, and 10 to 12 more niches can be found below-stairs from the main chamber in a chamber on the second level. A fourth chamber on a third level appears as an independent entity with its own entryway. The burial niches are arranged differently in each chamber, although each chamber is designed with an eye to [[symmetry]]. Stone [[ossuary|ossuaries]] were found in rock-cut vaults within the complex. All told, there are 63 burial niches in the tomb, along with several cubicles and niches for bone collection. In his 1847 book, ''The Lands of the Bible Visited and Described'', English archeologist John Wilson describes his exploration of the Tombs of the Sanhedrin:
"From the [[Tomb of Simeon the Just]], I proceeded further on, to the Tombs of the Sanhedrin. These, like the former, are under ground, hewn in the solid rock. The entrance here is still lower, and I was obliged, in some parts, to lay flat down and slide in; but when once inside, I found large vaulted chambers. I counted sixty-three niches where sarcophagi had formerly been placed. In each of these three tombs there were numberless names written on the walls by devout Jews who had visited them".
Opinions differ as to how the bodies were placed in the niches. According to Har-El, Jews placed their deceased either in stone [[Sarcophagus|sarcophagi]] in the niches or in ossuaries in vaults. Williams and Willis quote an archeologist who opines that the bodies, swathed in burial clothes, were placed directly into the niches, which were then closed or sealed with a stone slab.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6-o7AAAAcAAJ&pg=PA152|pages=152–156 |title=The Holy City: Historical, Topographical and Antiquarian Notices of Jerusalem, Volume 2 |first1=George |last1=Williams |authorlink1=George Williams (priest) |first2=Robert |last2=Willis |year=1849}} In 1867 a French archeologist investigating the tombs discovered a sarcophagus inscribed with the name ''Yitzchak'' (Isaac) in [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]]. Over the protests of local Jewish residents, the archeologist took the sarcophagus back with him to France, where it was displayed in the [[Musée du Louvre|Louvre Museum]].{{cite web |url=http://www.jerusalem.muni.il/jer_main/openTable.asp?src=/jer_sys/tour/vir_tour/show/results_heb.asp?Tour_Spons=4&cont=510 |script-title=he:קברי הסנהדרין|language=Hebrew |trans-title=Tombs of the Sanhedrin |publisher=Jerusalem Municipality |year=2008 |accessdate=31 October 2012}} ==Modern-day== Following the establishment of the State of Israel in May 1948, the [[Old City (Jerusalem)|Old City]] of Jerusalem was captured by the Arab Legion and was only reconquered by the Israelis in the [[Six-Day War]] of June 1967. Throughout that 19-year period, many ancient graves were off-limits to Jewish visitors, and the Tombs of the Sanhedrin became an oft-visited site as a result. Through the 20th century, the tombs were open to the public. In the 1930s, a young [[Shlomo Moussaieff (businessman)|Shlomo Moussaieff]] claimed he found ancient coins in the caves and sold them to support himself after his father threw him out of the house.{{cite web |url=http://www.haaretz.com/a-man-of-good-fortune-1.71559 |title=A Man of Good Fortune |date=10 October 2001 |accessdate=10 October 2012 |work=[[Haaretz]]}} In the 2000s, access to the Tombs was restricted due to vandalism and a gate was placed across the entrance. The tombs have been defaced by graffiti{{cite web |url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/as-state-slumbers-volunteers-step-in-to-rescue-neglected-sanhedrin-tombs-1.261396 |title=As state slumbers, volunteers step in to rescue neglected Sanhedrin Tombs |date=14 January 2010 |first=Nir|last=Hasson |accessdate=10 October 2012|work=Haaretz}} and the forecourt is often clogged with garbage and filth. Several clean-up efforts have been mounted by civilian volunteers.{{cite web |url=http://www.bhol.co.il/forums/topic.asp?cat_id=4&topic_id=2735949&forum_id=771&upd=1|script-title=he:לכלוך בקברי הסנהדרין? נסגור אותם|trans-title=Garbage in the Tombs of the Sanhedrin? Let’s close them |first=Tzofia |last=Hirshfeld |language=Hebrew|publisher=BeChadrei Charedim |date=23 December 2009 |accessdate=19 October 2012}} ==In popular culture== In the 1950s the State of Israel issued a [[Israeli lira|half-lira]] banknote that depicted the facade of the tombs. ==See also== *[[Rock-cut tombs in Israel]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{Cemeteries in Jerusalem}} {{coord|31|47|58|N|35|13|08|E|region:IL_type:landmark_source:kolossus-hewiki|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tombs of the Sanhedrin}} [[Category:Archaeological sites in Jerusalem]] [[Category:Burial monuments and structures]] [[Category:Cemeteries in Jerusalem]] [[Category:Jewish mausoleums]] [[Category:Rock-cut tombs]] [[Category:Historic sites in Jerusalem]]

'''Youmanity''' is a registered [[Charitable organization|charity]] founded in [[London]] in June 2008, designed to celebrate [[multiculturalism]], support [[social integration]] and promote [[human rights]]. It does this by delivering a number of cultural projects every year, including an annual photography award.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rps.org/news/2017/june/youmanity-winners-announced |title=RPS announces Youmanity's Award winners |date=25 June 2017}}</ref> Previous awards explored themes such as human trafficking<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7TxJ8EMdZCM| title=News Report on Youmanity's Human Trafficking Awareness Project |date=6 August 2013}}</ref>, social identity<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.timeout.com/london/art/home-my-place-in-the-world |title=Home, my Place in the World, an exhibition about Social Identity |website=Time Out|date=17 April 2013}}</ref>, freedom of expression<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dphoto.co.nz/photography-news-equipment-and-camera-reviews-and-tutorials-1/photography-news-6900/freedom-to-love-competition-winners-announced |title=Freedom to Love, Youmanity award winners |website= D-Photo |date=17 November 2014}}</ref>, gender discrimination<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rps.org/news/2017/march/the-everyday-heroine-call-for-entries |title=The Everyday Heroine |website= the Royal Photographic Society |date=16 March 2017}}</ref>. To date, Youmanity has received the patronage of the [[Imperial War Museum]]<ref>{{cite report |title=Annual Research Report |publisher=Imperial War Museum| date= 2014}}</ref>, [[Amnesty International]],<ref>{{cite web |url=https://archive.is/GgrW |title= Migration, Stories of a Journey, an exhibition in partnership with Amnesty International |date= 20 December 2011}}</ref> the [[British Council]], the [[European Commission]], the [[International Organisation for Migration]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iom.int/news/migration-stories-journey-accademia-apulia-photography-award-2011-winner-announced |title= Migration, Stories of a Journey as featured by IOM |date= 3 January 2012}}</ref>
